webTitle: Brexit: Corbyn 'very happy' to meet May to discuss compromise plan - as it happened

fields.headline: Brexit: Corbyn 'very happy' to meet May to discuss compromise plan - as it happened
fields.standfirst:
Rolling coverage of the day’s politics as they happen, including Theresa May chairing a five-hour cabinet meeting to decide what to do about Brexit

  • MPs seek to stop no-deal Brexit by tabling article 50 bill
  • No-deal Brexit more likely by the day, says Michel Barnier
  • Up to 20 Tories could vote against May in confidence vote - Davis
fields.trailText: Rolling coverage of the day’s politics as they happen, including Theresa May chairing a five-hour cabinet meeting to decide what to do about Brexit
fields.body:
12.03am BST

Closing summary

That’s all from us this evening, so here’s a summary of the day’s events:

  • The prime minister said she planned to ask the European Union for a further delay to Brexit. Speaking from Downing Street, Theresa May said she understood some people’s desire for a no-deal Brexit but that she wanted time to find a settlement. Any delay would end if and when a deal was struck, she said. The president of the European council, Donald Tusk, appeared to indicate the EU was minded to accede.
  • Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn are to meet to discuss a way to break the Brexit impasse. In the same address, the prime minister invited the Labour leader to talks on Tuesday after seven hours of cabinet discussions. Corbyn accepted the offer soon afterwards. It followed MPs’ failure to find an alternative way forward on Monday.
  • May’s plan called for the two leaders to agree a unified approach to put to MPs. If they couldn’t do so, the prime minister said she’d put forward a series of options and abide by MPs’ choice – as long as Corbyn also agreed to do the same.
  • Cabinet ministers were tight-lipped after their marathon meeting, amid reports of a split. Afterwards, the environment secretary Michael Gove spoke publicly in support of the prime minister’s approach.
  • But many senior Brexiters were unimpressed with May’s plan. Some members of the Tory backbench ERG attacked it, as did the DUP. Other senior parliamentarians, however, applauded the prime minister’s decision to try – after nearly three years – to find a consensus across the aisle.
  • Business leaders offered a cautious welcome. But many said they wanted to see Westminster get on with offering certainty over Brexit.
  • Earlier in the day, the Irish prime minister had said May must have a clear plan to be granted a further delay. Speaking alongside the French president, Emmanuel Macron, Leo Varadkar said the EU wanted to avoid a rolling Brexit.
  • The prime minister was accused of putting her party before the country. Nick Boles spoke out a day after quitting the Tory party over what he characterised as its intransigence over Brexit. But he was one of those to cautiously welcome May’s change of approach after her speech in the evening.

If you want to read more, my colleagues Rowena Mason, Peter Walker, Rajeev Syal and Heather Stewart have the full story:

Related: May calls for talks with Corbyn in bid to save Brexit

10.19pm BST

The hard Brexit-supporting DUP have released a statement on Theresa May’s offer to Jeremy Corbyn and, like the assessments of members of the similarly positioned ERG, it is scathing:

The prime minister’s lamentable handling of the negotiations with the EU means she has failed to deliver a sensible Brexit deal that works for all parts of the United Kingdom. That is why she has not been able to get it through parliament.

Her announcement therefore tonight comes as little surprise.

Though it remains to be seen if subcontracting out the future of Brexit to Jeremy Corbyn, someone whom the Conservatives have demonised for four years, will end happily.

We want the result of the referendum respected and, just as we joined the common market as one country, we must leave the EU as one country.

We will continue to use our position within Parliament and with the government to argue strongly the case for Northern Ireland and the integrity of the United Kingdom.

We remain consistent in judging all Brexit outcomes against our clear unionist principles.

9.33pm BST

Boris Johnson has told the BBC that people want politicians in Westminster “not to focus on themselves, but to focus on the needs of the country”.

9.16pm BST

The European Parliament’s Brexit coordinator, Guy Verhofstadt, damns May with faint praise:

8.43pm BST

A little more from Gove’s interview on Sky News: He insisted the Tory party would not split over May’s decision today.

I don’t think we’re splitting – I think what we’re doing is ensuring everybody is focused on making sure we leave the EU at the earliest possible point.

On the DUP saying they could not back the current deal, he said:

We want the DUP to support our approach. I think it’s important we leave the EU as one UK.

And, on his own leadership ambitions, he added:

I’m concentrating on making sure we leave the EU, that is front and centre of my mind and everything else is secondary.

8.16pm BST

There is now a conflicting report on the split in the cabinet, with another source telling the Press Association that ministers voted 17 to four in favour of the limited extension sought by the prime minister.

Gavin Williamson, Penny Mordaunt, Chris Grayling and Liz Truss opposed the extension, according to the source.

Of the 17 who backed it, Jeremy Wright and James Brokenshire made a point of saying they only wanted a short extension to the Article 50 process. The source said: “This is a pragmatic way forward. PM clear that we won’t leave with no deal in April.”

The environment secretary, Michael Gove, is now on Sky News defending the proposal, saying its most important facet is that it is limited and ends, unequivocally, with Brexit.

His former Vote Leave colleague, Boris Johnson, is less enthused:

Updated at 8.28pm BST

8.08pm BST

The director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, Carolyn Fairbairn, has echoed the words of other business leaders this evening, saying:

Welcome steps must be breakthrough, not false dawn. Business confidence slumping, growth stalled and UK reputation in tatters. Tories must compromise on red lines and Labour come to table in good faith. No excuses, no time wasting, no party politics. Enough is enough.

Dr Adam Marshall, the Director General of the British Chambers of Commerce, said:

The clock is still ticking and avoiding a messy and disorderly exit from the EU is still the top priority for our business communities. The government must take firm action now to ensure that this is not allowed to happen by default.

Yet businesses need to see outcomes, not just more process. Ongoing uncertainty is having a real and negative impact on business confidence and investment all across the UK. Our own quarterly survey of businesses is concrete evidence of this, with the worst figures across the board in nearly a decade.

The prime minister may have issued a revised road map, but business communities still have little sense of the destination. It’s like being asked to follow a sat-nav to an unknown location – with the nagging worry that the directions may yet lead to a cliff.

Updated at 8.13pm BST

8.06pm BST

The chair of the parliamentary home affairs select committee, Labour’s Yvette Cooper, has welcomed what she called the prime minister’s “recognition that she needs to avoid a damaging no-deal on April 12th”.

When the cabinet secretary and national security adviser to the government had advised the cabinet that no-deal would make the country less safe, it would have been irresponsible of them not to listen. We do need a sensible approach and the prime minister needs to find a way to bring the country together, not just Parliament.

We are waiting to find out further details on how the government’s proposed process will work, including how decisions will be taken about the length and purpose of an extension, and how indicative votes will work to make sure we don’t just end up with no-deal a bit later on.

8.03pm BST

The Labour party has just put out Corbyn’s response to May’s statement:

I’m very happy to meet the prime minister. I don’t want to set any limits, one way or the other, ahead of those meetings. We recognise that she has made a move. I recognise my responsibility to represent the people who supported Labour in the last election and the people who didn’t support Labour but nevertheless want certainty and security for their own future. And that’s the basis on which we will meet her and have those discussions.

Labour has put forward our proposals to ensure there is a customs union with the EU, access to vital markets and protections of our standards of consumer, environmental and workers’ rights. And we’ll ensure that those are on the table. We’re also very clear that there has to be an absolute guarantee that the Good Friday Agreement is maintained for peace in Northern Ireland.

So far, the prime minister hasn’t shown much sign of compromise but I’m pleased that today she’s indicated she’ll accept the view of Parliament and is prepared to reach out and have that discussion. I have been meeting MPs from all parties over the past weeks. And there is some common ground; there are some areas it’s difficult to agree on. But, however people voted in the referendum of 2016, they didn’t vote for lower living standards or to lose their jobs. And there’s far more that unites people on both sides than divides them.

7.59pm BST

Corbyn has refused to put limits on the talks and it appears May is making similar noises: Asked whether the prime minister would be willing to discuss proposals with Corbyn that would breach her “red lines” – such as taking the UK out of the customs union or ruling out a second referendum – a Downing Street source told reporters:

You know the prime minister’s views, but unless there is compromise on both sides, it is unlikely we can find a way forward. Jeremy Corbyn has to understand that too.

The source pointed out that the Commons had rejected a second referendum already. Downing Street is hoping that a meeting will happen “as soon as possible” but could give no timetable for the proposed votes.

7.55pm BST

Corbyn said:

However people voted in the referendum in 2016, whether they voted remain or they voted leave, they didn’t vote for lower living standards, they didn’t vote to lose their jobs.

And, actually, there’s far more that unites people on both sides about the kind of society we can be than divides them.

The Labour leader added that the question of whether the UK takes part in the EU elections was not the most important, rather that the most prominent issue was “to make sure we don’t crash out of the EU next week with no deal, and what I believe would be a degree of chaos that would follow as a result”.

Updated at 7.57pm BST

7.50pm BST

Corbyn also said that he would not set any “limits” ahead of the meeting with the prime minister, but that his principles ahead of it were to recognise the “needs of the people that elected all MPs to parliament and the need to avoid the dangers of crashing out”.

He said that Labour would “hold in reserve” the option of tabling a confidence motion in the government if it “proves it is incapable of commanding a majority in the House of Commons”, PA said.

Updated at 7.51pm BST

7.34pm BST

Corbyn has told the Press Association:

We will meet the prime minister. We recognise that she has made a move; I recognise my responsibility to represent the people that supported Labour in the last election and the people who didn’t support Labour but nevertheless want certainty and security for their own future, and that’s the basis on which we will meet her and we will have those discussions.

Updated at 7.39pm BST

7.29pm BST

Corbyn 'very happy' to meet May to discuss Brexit

The Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, has said he is “very happy” to meet Theresa May after she offered to sit down with him to agree a plan that will allow the UK to leave the EU with a deal.

Updated at 7.32pm BST

7.28pm BST

The hard Brexit-supporting Tory backbenchers in the ERG watched the prime minister’s announcement in a committee room 15 in the House of Commons. There was audible gasp when she said she would open discussions with Corbyn, said one attendee. The Tory MP, Conor Burns, added:

The UK no longer has a functioning government of executive control. The PM has handed the future decisions over Brexit to the Labour party. It will now be for Corbyn, Diane Abbott and John Mcdonnell to decide if the Conservative party implements its manifesto. It is a very bleak day.

The ERG chairman, Jacob Rees-Mogg, warned history did not show success for political leaders who tried to get policy through the Commons “on the back of opposition votes”.

This approach to government is an unsuccessful one and it also lacks democratic legitimacy. People did not vote for a Corbyn-May coalition government – they voted for a Conservative government, which became a confidence and supply with the DUP.

This is a deeply unsatisfactory approach. It’s not in the interests of the country; it fails to deliver on the referendum result and history doesn’t bode well for it.

Rees-Mogg criticised the prime minister for planning to work with with a “known Marxist” and said the move would lose Tory votes.

You do find that leaders who decide to go with the opposition rather than their own party find their own party doesn’t plainly follow.

I’m not sure this is the way to conciliate people to persuade them if they haven’t moved already to move at this stage.

I think getting the support of a known Marxist is not likely to instil confidence in Conservatives.

Updated at 7.35pm BST

7.16pm BST

There are reports around that not everyone in the cabinet was thrilled with the prime minister’s approach.

In her speech (see: 6.36pm), May did not claim to have reached unanimous agreement with ministers.

Of course, disagreements around the table are not unusual, though the convention is that ministers are expected, eventually, to agree to abide by a collective decision. And, as yet, no cabinet minister has been willing to publicly discuss their thoughts on May’s statement.

7.02pm BST

Edwin Morgan, the interim director general of the business group, the Institute of Directors, has welcomed the prime minister’s step,while warning that there are “still many obstacles on the path ahead”.

There was a clear indication of how the government sees the next steps unfolding but time is of the essence and the outcome of all this is still far from clear.

The brinkmanship has gone on for far too long and business leaders want our politicians to put an end to this miserable uncertainty. We urge the leader of the opposition to work with the prime minister to find a solution. Both sides must play ball.

Ian Wright, the chief executive of the Food and Drink Federation, also called on the country’s political leadership to ensure she comes up with a workable plan quickly:

Livelihoods are at stake, jobs are on the line. Food and drink manufacturers are spending money, time and effort trying to plan under a cloud of perpetual uncertainty.

A further extension to article 50 must be sufficient to allow for a new plan to emerge. Unless the prime minister can secure the speedy support of the leader of the opposition, another short extension would only prolong the misery for businesses and the country.

Updated at 7.07pm BST

6.56pm BST

The environment secretary, Michael Gove, is the latest to studiously ignore the television camera in his face as he leaves Downing Street.

Even if cabinet ministers are keeping quiet, we’re getting some political reaction to the PM’s statement. The leader of the SNP, Nicola Sturgeon, accuses the prime minister of kicking the can down the road.

Liz Saville Roberts, Plaid Cymru’s Westminster leader, prefers to put the focus on the Labour party:

Alistair Burt, who resigned as a Foreign Office minister last week so that he could vote for the Letwin amendment allowing MPs to take charge of the Commons timetable, had praise for Theresa May:

The Liberal Democrats less so. The party’s leader, Vince Cable, said:

The prime minister’s statement could be a case of piling more logs onto the logjam. Liberal Democrats are clear – Brexit, whether Labour-red or Tory-blue would be hugely damaging for the country.

Theresa May now finally seems to be accepting that she cannot get support for her deal, though her identifying Jeremy Corbyn as a source of support for Brexit is less surprising.

The way forward, to break the impasse, is for the prime minister to compromise and support a People’s Vote, with the option to stay in the European Union.

Its Brexit spokesman, Tom Brake, tweeted:

The remain-supporting former Tory MP, Anna Soubry, was no less critical of the prime minister:

And the Tory Brexiter, Andrew Bridgen, dismissed May’s’s statement, telling the Guardian:

In effectively putting Jeremy Corbyn in charge of the outcome of Brexit, the prime minister will have further diminished herself in the eyes of her MPs, activists and our supporters. It’s desperate stuff.

6.45pm BST

We’re expecting a response from the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, to Theresa May’s offer to meet him for Brexit talks within the next 15 minutes or so. We’ll bring you that when we have it, obviously.

6.40pm BST

The president of the European council, Donald Tusk, is apparently indicating that he may be open to Theresa May’s suggestion of a further delay to Brexit:

Updated at 6.42pm BST

6.36pm BST

Here is the full text of the prime minister’s statement, delivered from Downing Street about half an hour ago:

I have just come from chairing seven hours of cabinet meetings focused on finding a route out of the current impasse – one that will deliver the Brexit the British people voted for and allow us to move on and begin bringing our divided country back together.

I know there are some who are so fed up with delay and endless arguments that they would like to leave with no deal next week.

I have always been clear that we could make a success of no deal in the long term. But leaving with a deal is the best solution. So, we will need a further extension of article 50 – one that is as short as possible and which ends when we pass a deal. And we need to be clear what such an extension is for – to ensure we leave in a timely and orderly way.

This debate, this division, cannot drag on much longer. It is putting members of Parliament and everyone else under immense pressure and it is doing damage to our politics.

Despite the best efforts of MPs, the process that the House of Commons has tried to lead has not come up with an answer. So, today, I am taking action to break the logjam: I am offering to sit down with the leader of the opposition and to try to agree a plan – that we would both stick to – to ensure that we leave the European Union and that we do so with a deal.

Any plan would have to agree the current withdrawal agreement – it has already been negotiated with the 27 other members, and the EU has repeatedly said that it cannot and will not be reopened.

What we need to focus on is our future relationship with the EU. The ideal outcome of this process would be to agree an approach on a future relationship that delivers on the result of the referendum, that both the leader of the opposition and I could put to the house for approval, and which I could then take to next week’s European council.

However, if we cannot agree on a single unified approach, then we would instead agree a number of options for the future relationship that we could put to the house in a series of votes to determine which course to pursue. Crucially, the government stands ready to abide by the decision of the house. But, to make this process work, the opposition would need to agree to this too.

The government would then bring forward the withdrawal agreement bill. We would want to agree a timetable for this bill to ensure it is passed before 22 May so that the United Kingdom need not take part in European parliamentary elections.

This is a difficult time for everyone. Passions are running high on all sides of the argument. But we can and must find the compromises that will deliver what the British people voted for. This is a decisive moment in the story of these islands. And it requires national unity to deliver the national interest.

Updated at 6.44pm BST

6.27pm BST

In the minutes since Theresa May finished delivering her statement, cabinet ministers have been filing out of Downing Street.

Sajid Javid, Jeremy Hunt, Liz Truss, James Brokenshire, Amber Rudd, Chris Grayling and Damian Hinds left via the front door of Number 10. The Tory party chairman, Brandon Lewis, followed soon after.

But none offered any comment.

6.26pm BST

Nick Boles, who quit the Conservative party on Monday over what he characterised as its intransigence on Brexit, has had this to say following the prime minister’s statement:

6.14pm BST

May says the extension would be “as short as possible” and would end once a deal was struck.

She says any plan both she and Corbyn agreed upon would then be put to MPs for approval with a view to it being taken to next week’s European council meeting.

If she and Corbyn cannot agree a unified approach, May says, then a series of options for the future relationship would be put to the Commons in a series of votes. The prime minister adds that the government would abide by the decision of the house – but only if Labour did so too.

May also says she wants the process to be finished by 22 May so that the UK does not have to take part in the European parliament elections.

Updated at 6.19pm BST

6.09pm BST

Prime minister calls for further Brexit delay

Theresa May says she understands some people are so fed up that they want to leave with no deal. But she supports leaving with one and says we need a short extension to article 50.

She says the debate cannot be allowed to drag on and adds that the Commons’ approach has not worked.

May says she is offering to sit down with the leader of the opposition, Jeremy Corbyn, to come up with a plan to leave with a deal. But she says that deal must include her withdrawal agreement.

6.06pm BST

The prime minister is starting her speech.

5.49pm BST

We’ve posted a live feed of the prime minister’s speech at the top of the page, so you’ll be able to watch it live once she starts speaking.

Updated at 5.58pm BST

5.43pm BST

Good evening. We’re expecting the prime minister to make a statement soon, so we’ll bring you news of that as it happens.

In the meantime, it appears ministers who attended the cabinet meeting are still inside Number 10 and there is speculation that the prime minister may be about to soften some of her red lines.

Updated at 5.44pm BST

5.31pm BST

Nick Boles accuses May of putting party before country over Brexit

The BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg has interviewed Nick Boles, who resigned the Tory whip last night because his party was unwilling to compromise over Brexit. (Boles tabled the common market 2.0 amendment.) Here are the highlights.

That is all from me for today.

My colleague Kevin Rawlinson is taking over now.

5.25pm BST

This is from Sky’s Jon Craig.

5.24pm BST

Earlier this afternoon the Commons passed a motion admonishing Dominic Cummings, the campaign director of Vote Leave, for contempt of parliament, because he refused to give evidence to a culture committee inquiry into “fake news” and disinformation. Speaking in the debate Damian Collins, the committee chair, said parliament should have the power to fine people or even send them to prison, as is the case in some other countries, for this sort of offence. He said:

I do not believe it is good enough for witnesses just to create reasons why they’d rather not give evidence. Otherwise that undermines the whole process, If witnesses decline to give evidence simply because it is unsatisfactory to them, its not appropriate.

We have to accept that if we don’t take our own powers seriously other people will behave in the same way. Other people will look at this case and say you can simply ignore it, you can ignore their request, there is nothing they can do.

Collins said in other parliaments around the world there are rules that meant people who refused to give evidence, or even sent to jail for a short period. Any decisions of that kind should not be taken by politicians, but by an independent body, he said.

5.15pm BST

Penny Mordaunt has not resigned as international development secretary, the Telegraph’s Gordon Rayner reports.

See 5.07pm if you are wondering why people thought she might have done.

5.12pm BST

My colleague Jennifer Rankin has written a good article on EU thinking about Brexit. Here is an extract.

So no deal is off the table?

Not yet. No deal is the legal default, so cannot be ruled out. While the EU would probably grant an extension, officials in Brussels are not certain the prime minister will ask for one. EU leaders will not force the UK into a long extension if it does not seek one or refuses to meet the terms, say people close to the process. Some fear May would placate her party over taking part in European elections. “If the prime minister said she wanted a no deal, we wouldn’t be able to stop her jumping off the cliff,” the EU diplomat said.

And here is the whole thing.

Related: Brussels on Brexit: would EU leaders say yes to an extension?

5.07pm BST

These are from Sky’s Faisal Islam.

Updated at 5.08pm BST

5.05pm BST

This is from ITV’s Robert Peston.

5.05pm BST

The senior Lib Dem MP Norman Lamb (he was not far off being elected leader in 2015) has told the BBC that he is considering resigning the party whip because he is so angry about how the Lib Dems acted in the indicative votes last night. Lamb voted for the customs union amendment, but around half of colleagues voted against it along with other MPs who did not want it to succeed because they want a second referendum instead.

He said he was worried the Lib Dems were turing into “the mirror image of the ERG”.

4.47pm BST

Cabinet is finally coming to an end, Sky’s Beth Rigby reports.

Updated at 5.52pm BST

4.34pm BST

Leo Varadkar says May must have 'clear purpose and plan' to justify further article 50 extension

Speaking in Paris alongside Emmanuel Macron, Leo Varadkar, the Irish prime minister, said Theresa May would have to come up with a “clear pathway to success” to justify another article 50 extension. He explained:

At the last European council meeting we gave the UK some time and space to come up with [a] way forward. As it stands they will leave the EU on April 12 without a deal. However, there is still time for the prime minister to come to the council with proposals – proposals that are credible and have clear pathway to success and we need to be open to any proposals she might bring forward to us.

Varadkar also said the EU would want to avoid “a rolling extension”. He went on:

Any extension must have a clear purpose and plan.

Updated at 4.54pm BST

4.22pm BST

Yvette Cooper is now planning to get MPs to pass her bill tomorrow requiring the PM to request an article 50 extension, the Mirror’s Dan Bloom reports. Originally the plan was for MPs to debate it on Thursday.

Here is the business motion.

4.16pm BST

Cabinet ministers have been in Number 10 for almost seven hours now, and their meeting is still going on. They could be there for another hour, according to ITV’s Adrian Masters.

4.13pm BST

Simon Coveney, the Irish deputy prime minister, told the Irish parliament today that a no-deal Brexit was now a very real possibility. Speaking in the Dáil, he said:

I agree with Michel Barnier and others when they say that, when the days pass, a no-deal Brexit looks like a very real possibility.

He also said Ireland was not going to allow a situation where the UK leaving the EU without a deal “drags Ireland out of the single market with it”. He said:

Checks in EU ports on all Irish products - that is not a runner, and will cause significant damage to our economy, so we will not allow it.

Coveney said Ireland and the European commission were trying to work out how best to respond to a no-deal scenario to ensure the Good Friday agreement was protected, but also that physical infrastructure on the border was avoided.

Updated at 4.56pm BST

3.52pm BST

'We cannot avoid failure for them' - Macron says it will be UK's fault, not EU's, if there's no-deal

The French president, Emmanuel Macron, warmly greeted the Irish taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, for talks at the Élysée promising total “unity and solidarity” towards Ireland by all other EU member states over Brexit.

Before the two leaders retired to discuss no-deal planning and next week’s emergency summit, Macron said it was now up to the UK to provide an “alternative plan supported by a majority” before 10 April.

He warned that a long extension could not be taken for granted, warning it would be neither easy “nor automatic”. He said:

A long extension involving the participation of the UK in European elections and European institutions is far from evident and certainly not [to be taken] for granted.

Our priority shall be the good functioning of the EU and the single market. The EU cannot sustainably be the hostage to the solution to a political crisis in the UK.

We cannot spend the coming months sorting out yet again the terms of our divorce and dealing with the past.

Macron said credible justifications for an article 50 extension could include an election, second referendum or alternative proposals for the future relationship, such as a customs union. The EU would be “open” to such proposals, but it was for London to put them forward, he said. “It’s up to London to say it, and to say it now.”

If there were a no-deal Brexit, it would be the UK’s fault, he added.

Should the United Kingdom be unable to – three years after the referendum – propose a solution backed by a majority, they will de facto have chosen for themselves to leave without a deal. We cannot avoid failure for them.

Macron also said that France and Ireland would be the EU nations most directly affected by no-deal.

I’m fully aware of the tremendous difficulties such a situation would bring about for Ireland. We will never abandon Ireland or the Irish people, no matter what happens, because this solidarity is the very purpose of the European project.

Updated at 4.57pm BST

3.37pm BST

There again, those rumours may be duff.

3.34pm BST

This is from ITV’s Paul Brand.

3.32pm BST

Long article 50 extension 'will happen', says SNP's Ian Blackford

Ian Blackford, the Scottish National party leader at Westminster, has said he is convinced the UK and EU will agree a lengthy extension to article 50 to allow extra time to cope with the Brexit crisis. He told the Guardian:

A long extension will happen. I’m not just saying that: we know that will happen. We’ve been speaking to people in the EU and the EU is desperate for the signal to be given by parliament which gives them the excuse for a long extension. It will happen, I’m pretty clear on that.

Blackford said intensive cross-party talks were now under way among MPs anxious to find a compromise deal on a far softer Brexit which would be good enough to win a Commons majority following the failure of all four alternative options on Monday night. That would then present the EU with the pretext for delaying Brexit for months.

He defended the SNP’s decision to abstain on the Ken Clarke proposal to require customs union membership, insisting it failed to meet the SNP’s key tests on freedom of movement and free access for the banking, finance and services sector to the EU.

Clarke’s motion came the closest to success, losing by just three votes on Monday. The SNP, which has the greatest voting discipline of the parties on Brexit, commands 35 votes. Blackford insisted he and Nicola Sturgeon, the SNP leader and first minister, “don’t want to be obstructive” but Clarke’s motion “didn’t go nearly far enough”.

Blackford said the SNP’s primary goal was either suspending article 50 or forcing a new Brexit referendum but its decision to support the Nick Boles motion, the so-called common market 2.0 option, which involves UK joining the European free trade area Efta, was proof the party was willing to compromise, since the Boles motion was also imperfect, he said.

“We have to have generosity of spirit, but it has to be over things that get us to a better place than where we are,” he said. “There are an awful lot of conversations going on” focused on finding a new soft Brexit formula which might finally win a Commons majority.

Updated at 4.59pm BST

3.27pm BST

These are from the BBC’s Katya Adler about the emergency EU summit in Brussels on Wednesday next week.

3.23pm BST

And here are some lines from what Leo Varadkar, the Irish PM, said when he was speaking alongside the French president, Emmanuel Macron.

These are from my colleagues Lisa O’Carroll.

3.14pm BST

Macron says EU granting long article 50 extension cannot be 'taken for granted'

Emmanuel Macron, the French president, has been meeting Leo Varadkar, the Irish prime minister, in Paris today to discuss Brexit.

Macron stressed that it was not inevitable that the EU would grant the UK a long article 50 extension.

These are from my colleague Angelique Chrisafis, RTE’s Tony Connelly and the Mail’s Jason Groves.

Updated at 3.59pm BST

3.06pm BST

Jo Maugham, the QC who was one of those behind the case taken to the European court of justice to establish that the UK has the power to revoke article 50 unilaterally, has been looking at the detail of the Cooper bill, and he is not impressed. He explains why in a Twitter thread starting here.

Nikki da Costa, the former director of legislative affairs for Theresa May in Downing Street, says she agrees with Maugham’s analysis.

2.55pm BST

Philippe Lamberts, the Belgian MEP who is co-president of the Greens in the European parliament and who sits on the parliament’s Brexit steering group, told the World at One that British politicians were wrong if they thought the EU could not accept a no-deal Brexit. Asked if the EU would act to avoid no-deal at all costs, he replied:

No, that’s exactly the mistake and a misreading that happens all the time.

It’s not at any cost because if the cost of avoiding no deal is substantially bigger damage to the EU, namely to the integrity of the single market, then between two evils we will choose the lesser one.

Lamberts also said that MPs who thought the Malthouse compromise (a plan for the UK to effectively have a transition, without agreeing to the backstop) would work were “deluding themselves”. He went on:

I have seen too much of that over the last two years in Westminster. I’m afraid the harsh reality is quite different and if people cannot come to terms with reality then the wake-up will be difficult.

Only this morning Damian Green, the Tory pro-European and the former first secretary of state, was claiming that the EU might accept a version of the Malthouse compromise. This is from Sky’s Greg Heffer.

2.42pm BST

2.29pm BST

Scottish parliament prepares to cancel Easter recess in event of no-deal Brexit

The Scottish parliament’s Easter holidays next week could be cancelled if the UK is facing a no-deal Brexit, Nicola Sturgeon told her cabinet this morning.

The first minister’s spokesman said after the Scottish cabinet met that the Scottish National party’s business manager at Holyrood, Graeme Dey, had begun talks with opposition parties about suspending the Easter recess, which starts on Saturday and lasts until Sunday 21 April.

Philip Sim, a BBC Scotland politics reporter, quoted Sturgeon’s spokesman saying: “MSPs should not be on holiday when the biggest, most momentous, potentially most damaging issue to hit Scotland and the UK since WW2 is about to take place.”

A Scottish parliament spokeswoman said there were two options: either cancel recess in advance and timetable parliamentary business for next week, or continue with recess on the basis Holyrood could be urgently recalled if a no-deal Brexit took place. She said the parties’ business managers discussed it today but would decide the best course on Thursday.

There is a crucial subtext to this: if the Commons and UK government fail to agree a strategy to prevent the UK crashing out of the EU on Friday 12 April, that will add real urgency to the question of whether Sturgeon should call for a second independence referendum, or at the very least seek the powers to stage one.

The ongoing chaos over Brexit has led Sturgeon to repeatedly delay giving her long-promised update to the Scottish parliament on how, if and when she plans to hold that second referendum. The clash in timing of the 12 April deadline and Holyrood’s recess would otherwise deprive Sturgeon of a significant political opportunity to pivot from Brexit to independence.

While she knows Theresa May is extremely unlikely to grant Holyrood the powers to do so, and Scottish voters are currently unpersuaded of the case for a new referendum, Sturgeon will want to control the narrative in Scotland as best and as quickly as she can.

Updated at 2.37pm BST

2.24pm BST

Staying in customs union would not be 'true Brexit', says Jeremy Hunt

During Foreign Office questions in the Commons earlier, Jeremy Hunt, the foreign secretary, said that staying in the customs union would not be seen as a “true Brexit”. Responding to a question from Greg Hands, the former international trade minister, who asked what assessment the Foreign Office had made of the customs union option, Hunt said:

I think people would see it as very curious that a country that voted to take back control is choosing to cede control in a number of areas of vital national interest.

And I think they’d also be concerned that it would not resolve the national debate on Brexit because many of the people who voted for Brexit would not see this as delivering a true Brexit.

2.14pm BST

This is from my colleague Rowena Mason.

2.13pm BST

2.11pm BST

Alistair Burt, who resigned as a Foreign Office minister last week so that he could vote for the Letwin amendment allowing MPs to take charge of the Commons timetable, told the World at One that he wanted all minsters to be aware of the consequences of a no-deal Brexit. He said:

I was one of the ministers who quite specifically asked for advice as to whether the UK would be less safe and less secure if there was no deal.

That information needs to be available to ministers as they make a decision and my understanding is the cabinet secretary’s view of no deal is it is extremely damaging to the UK and I would hope that will pull many ministers away from that idea.

So we must find an alternative and I am very willing to keep trying on that.

1.47pm BST

From ITV’s Paul Brand

1.44pm BST

A question from BTL.

It is not so much a matter of the government’s language changing; it would be more accurate, I think, to say that different ministers have expressed themselves in different ways, depending on how supportive they are of her strategy. Some of them have said MPs must pass her deal; others (as you say) talk about the need to pass “a” deal.

But I’m not picking up any real openness to alternative deals. There was a stage, shortly before the government lost meaningful vote two (MV2), when ministers like David Gauke and Greg Clark sounded genuinely hopeful that an indicative votes process might generate parliamentary support for a softer Brexit. But, in the light of the 12 no votes on Wednesday last week and last night, that optimism seems to be fading.

And when you ask Number 10 about alternatives to May’s, you quickly hit a brick wall. Re-negotiating the backstop? They don’t think that’s possible. A customs union? But the UK would not be able to strike its own trade deal? Norway? Ending free movement is a firm red line. And a second referendum? God forbid.

1.25pm BST

Oliver Letwin says passing Cooper bill will be 'difficult' (and why he's right)

Sir Oliver Letwin, who is supporting the Cooper bill (see 12.56pm), has also issued a statement about the bill. But he sounds a bit more downbeat about its chances than Yvette Cooper herself. He says:

This is a last-ditch attempt to prevent our country being exposed to the risks inherent in a no-deal exit. We realise this is difficult. But it is definitely worth trying.

Why is Letwin saying passing the bill will be difficult? Because this move is unprecedented, and it could easily flounder in the House of Lords.

There is nothing unusual about parliament passing a backbench bill. There is an established system for this, the private members’ bills system, and several bills get published this way every year.

But what Cooper and Letwin are trying is different. They have used an amendment to a business motion to seize control of the Commons timetable to create time for MPs to pass a bill against the wishes of the government. There is no precedent for this in modern times.

One problem for Cooper and Letwin is that MPs may feel they are abusing the process. On Monday last week, when originally passed the Letwin amendment allowing him to take control of Commons business for one day, it was to allow an indicative votes debate on Wednesday 27 March. But it has become a self-perpetuating process, and on the Wednesday Letwin grabbed a second day (yesterday), yesterday he grabbed a third day (tomorrow) and tomorrow he will grab a fourth (Thursday). Until now Letwin has maintained his 40-odd majority for all the business motions he has to pass, but some MPs may argue that he is abusing the process.

But the main problem is that Cooper cannot be sure to fast-track her bill through the House of Lords. The Commons cannot tell the Lords what to do, and in the upper chamber bills cannot be subject to programme motions saying they have to pass within a certain time limit. In theory, peers can drag on proceedings as long as they like. In practice this tends not to happen, but there are some hardline Brexiters in the chamber and they could decide to disrupt the Cooper bill, arguing that they are entitled to hold it up because it is setting a new constitutional precedent.

Updated at 1.29pm BST

12.56pm BST

Yvette Cooper unveils plan to let MPs vote for bill forcing May to extend article 50

The Labour MP Yvette Cooper has now published the text of her EU (withdrawal) (no 5) bill (see 12.20pm) - her attempt to legislate to force Theresa May to request an extension to article 50. Here is the plan.

  • Cooper and her allies plan to use tomorrow, which has been set aside for a third day of Oliver Letwin backbench business, not government business, to pass another business motion setting aside Thursday for a debate on Cooper’s bill. The text of that motion will be out tomorrow. If it passes ...
  • MPs would debate all stages of the Cooper bill on Thursday.
  • MPs would also hold more indicative votes on Thursday.
  • The bill would then go to the House of Lords, where a majority of peers have already agreed in principle that a Brexit bill coming from the Commons should be considered as soon as possible.

The Cooper bill would require the PM to come forward with a plan to extend article 50 for MPs to vote on. The PM would be able to choose how long the extension should be. And, if the EU were to offer an alternative length for an extension, that would have to come back for a vote.

Commenting on her bill, Cooper said:

We are now in a really dangerous situation with a serious and growing risk of no deal in 10 days’ time.

The prime minister has a responsibility to prevent that happening. She needs to put forward a proposal, including saying how long an extension she thinks we need to sort things out

If the government won’t act urgently, then parliament has a responsibility to try to ensure that happens even though we are right up against the deadline.

Parliament has tried to jam into two days a process of finding consensus that I wish the prime minister had started two years ago. But right now nothing has been agreed. So that means that whatever happens in the next few days, the UK needs an extension beyond 12 April if we are to avoid the damage and chaos of no-deal.

For the sake of jobs, public services and our national security we need to avert no deal.

Updated at 1.12pm BST

12.28pm BST

These are from the Financial Times’ Sebastian Payne on the political cabinet.

12.20pm BST

It looks as if the Conservative MP Oliver Letwin might be abandoning attempts to use indicative votes to find a Brexit consensus in the Commons. Because of the business motion passed yesterday, Wednesday will still be set aside for backbench Brexit business, instead of government business, but now that could be used for votes designed to stop a no-deal Brexit.

This is from Sky’s Beth Rigby.

And this is from my colleague Heather Stewart.

Yvette Cooper, who along with Nick Boles and Oliver Letwin has been taking a lead in Commons efforts to block a no-deal Brexit, is presenting a new backbench bill on this topic in the Commons today. It’s the EU (withdrawal) (no 5) bill.

Updated at 12.42pm BST

12.10pm BST

You can read all the Guardian’s Brexit coverage here. And here are two Brexit articles around elsewhere this morning that are worth reading.

  • William Hague, the former Conservative leader and former foreign secretary, says in the Daily Telegraph (paywall) that the next party leader could inherit a “ruin”. He says:

The Conservative party, I sense, is in danger of losing the support of hopeful young people with ambitions, and it cannot win elections without such people. Moreover, the Conservatives are inevitably identified with the Brexit project, for good or ill, and slowly, steadily, the case for Brexit is being lost.

I say that with regret, because by far the best course after the 2016 referendum has been to deliver Brexit and make a go of it. Now, however, a slow movement is taking place out there that makes it rather doubtful that people would vote for it again. Perhaps for the first time, everyone is talking about it, and they are beginning to notice that the trade deals are not so easy, the process of leaving extremely complicated and the keenest Brexiteers deeply divided among themselves. Most people haven’t changed their minds, but I meet some who have, as shown in polls as well.

The Conservatives thus face the terrible double prospect of voters shifting away from supporting their central policy, while those who do support it become enraged by the failure to deliver it. That’s why there is nothing guaranteed about having 316 seats in the Commons, nothing at all certain about having a Conservative government, and every possibility of leadership candidates finding they are leading not very much at all.

  • Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair’s former communications chief and a prominent People’s Vote campaigner, has written in the New European a speech he thinks Theresa May should give. He would like her to abandon her deal, and act as a neutral umpire in a referendum. He imagines May saying:

The Brexit side must be obliged to submit a plan that is clear, credible, deliverable, negotiable in Europe, rooted in the real world. And those who argue for staying in must also address the concerns people have that led so many to want to leave the EU. I shall be, now and in any referendum which follows, neutral as this straight choice is developed. Real plans have to be brought forward and agreed by both sides as the choice we put to the country.

This process needs time. The worst thing we could do is snatch at a solution based on the indicative votes process, which has failed to deliver the clarity many hoped it would.

I shall therefore be requesting a long extension from the EU. I have indicated my intentions to several of my fellow leaders and I am confident we will get the time needed.

Updated at 12.45pm BST

12.04pm BST

This is from the BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg.

This would be no great surprise in the light of the repeated hints being dropped in the chamber by John Bercow, the Speaker, about how he is going to apply a hardline interpretation of the rule about not putting the same proposition to a vote twice. Last week he said he would not allow a repeat vote on the PM’s deal just because support for it had gone up, and that he thought MPs needed protection from being asked to take the same difficult voting decision more than once.

Yesterday, after the Tory Brexiter Richard Drax used a point of order to say he bitterly regretted voting for the PM’s deal on Friday and that it must “never ever see the light of day again”, Bercow responded by saying:

[Drax] is a person of integrity and a man of principle. I respect what he said, and I think it stands for others to judge, but I appreciate his saying so candidly what he wanted to say.

Updated at 12.43pm BST

11.30am BST

We’ve had the regular No 10 morning briefing, but with a lengthy cabinet meeting (it will “last as long as it lasts”, we were told) still going on, there was not much new to learn. Theresa May’s spokesman was asked for the reaction to last night’s indicative votes, and he told reporters:

It is the second time that the house has considered a wide variety of options for a way forward, and it once again failed to find a clear majority in favour of any of those options. The government continues to believe it’s in the best interests of the country to leave with a deal. As you know, cabinet is meeting today to give further consideration to the results and how we should proceed.

And that was pretty much it.

Updated at 12.45pm BST

11.29am BST

Nigel Farage, the former Ukip leader, has responded to Michel Barnier’s comment about Farage and some fellow Brexiters wanting to “destroy the EU”. (See 9.28am.)

He is not saying that Barnier was wrong ...

11.07am BST

The European commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, has called for EU member states to remain united as the UK grapples with Brexit.

“You saw that the British parliament was unable to make a decision yesterday that would move towards a solution agreed by all,” he said after a meeting with the Italian prime minister, Giuseppe Conte, in Rome on Tuesday.

“The government is in session this morning ... we await the outcome of this meeting,” he added, while referring back to his comments last week comparing the British parliament to an Egyptian sphinx. “If we compare the sphinx and Great Britain, the sphinx would look like an open book,” he said.

Conte said Italy was preparing for a no-deal scenario. “We still have no clarity from the UK’s position on how to manage such a complex process,” he said. “For this reason, Italy is preparing for the unwelcome prospect of a no-deal.”

Updated at 11.44am BST

10.58am BST

One “minor benefit” of the Brexit crisis, the former foreign secretary Jack Straw revealed last night, is that people no longer berate him on the tube, accusing him of being a “war criminal”. Nowadays, he told a public meeting on Peace vs Justice at Inner Temple Hall in central London, they buttonhole him and tell him that politics wasn’t so chaotic in his day.

Straw, who was in the Labour cabinet during the Iraq war, defended the legality of the conflict and also disclosed that he regretted having to release General Augusto Pinochet after he was given evidence that the Chilean dictator was not medically fit to stand trial.

Updated at 11.46am BST

10.56am BST

Barnier says UK is undergoing a crisis that goes beyond Brexit

Here is more on what Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator, told the European parliament’s committee on foreign affairs this morning. I have taken the quotes from the Press Association.

  • Barnier said the crisis in the UK went beyond Brexit. He said:

I don’t think I need to go on at great length about the nature of what is going on in the UK, the impasse or political crisis they might be experiencing.

More deeply, it is not just about the question of Brexit. I don’t think it’s just about the question of Brexit and the agreement that’s on the table and the backstop for Ireland.

It is more broad than that. Somewhere along the line, it is a crisis that equally could have sprung up in another country.

In my country [France] as well, there are questions about what our relationship is to the world, what is our place in the EU, what is our economic model. These are all things coming out as a result of the British debate as well.

  • He said a no-deal Brexit would threaten UK-EU cooperation on security. He said:

We need to be aware of the implications of a no-deal for our security partnership.

There will be a break in the level of talks, less mutual commitment, risks to intelligence pooling. There might be inconsistencies in applying sanctions regimes because of a low level of cooperation.

The UK would no longer be taking part in EU operations or in the European Defence Agency’s capacity-building programmes ...

No deal for some time poses the threat of there being no organised framework... Come what may, we must fend off the risk of strategic divergence.

  • He said a no-deal Brexit would sour relations between the UK and the EU. He said:

If there is no deal, the atmosphere will be different. The lack of a deal means a lack of faith, a lack of a deal means a rupture in confidence between us.

  • He said a no-deal Brexit would not remove issues like Ireland and the UK’s financial contribution to the EU from the debate because as soon as the UK opened trade talks with the EU, these issues would reappear. In response to a question from a British MEP, he said:

[After no deal] there won’t be many months passing before the UK will start asking for negotiations on a free trade agreement or other issues, like transport.

The topics of Brexit will still be there – Ireland, the financial resolution, the legal obligations of the UK, the issues of citizens and citizens’ rights. These are questions we will put again and again.

If there is no deal and the UK wants to discuss trade or other subjects, we will put the same subjects back on the table.

Updated at 11.48am BST

10.40am BST

David Davis says up to 20 Tory MPs could vote against May in confidence motion over Brexit

There has been speculation about Theresa May trying to get her Brexit deal through parliament by linking it somehow to a confidence motion, ie, threatening a general election if she is defeated. It is not entirely clear how this would work, because the Fixed-term Parliaments Act means a prime minister can no longer simply declare that a vote is a confidence issue, and if the government does lose a confidence vote under the FTPA, an election would only happen if no one else can form an administration capable of winning a confidence vote within 14 days.

But that has not stopped the idea being discussed at Westminster.

In an interview with the BBC, David Davis, who resigned as Brexit secretary last summer because he opposed Theresa May’s Chequers plan, said that if May sought a long extension to article 50, that would “tear apart” the Tories. He went on:

I’d only make one warning to the cabinet ... don’t be sure that every Conservative MP would vote for you if it was made a confidence vote.

One or two of them have said already ... and, I think, probably about 20 of them would say, this, actually, is so important, it’s the future of our country.

It’s our destiny at stake. It’s more important than the Tory party.

Yesterday both Steve Baker (here) and Crispin Blunt (here) suggested they would be willing to vote against the government in a confidence motion if May backed the UK staying in a customs union.

Updated at 11.54am BST

10.21am BST

The Daily Mail, which is supportive of Theresa May at the moment, has an exclusive story about a letter from Sir Mark Sedwill, the cabinet secretary, to cabinet ministers about the dangers of a no-deal Brexit. It may not have been one of those letters written deliberately so that it would be leaked, but one assumes Downing Street will not be too upset about its appearance in the public domain.

Here is an extract from Jason Groves’ story in the Mail.

Sir Mark’s 14-page letter warns:

  • No-deal would result in a 10 per cent spike in food prices and the collapse of some businesses that trade with the EU;
  • The government would come under pressure to bail out companies on the brink;
  • It would hamper the ability of the police and security services to keep people safe;
  • It would lead to the reintroduction of direct rule in Northern Ireland for the first time since 2007;
  • A recession will hit the UK and the pound’s depreciation will be ‘more harmful’ than in 2008.
  • Our legal authorities and judicial system would be put under ‘enormous pressure’ ...

The letter will now be kept in the government’s files and could be released in the event of a public inquiry into the handling of Brexit.

Sir Mark, who also serves as the government’s national security adviser, warns that no-deal would affect our security services. ‘Our national security would be disrupted,’ he says. ‘The UK would forfeit access to criminal justice levers. None of our mitigation measures would give the UK the same security capabilities as our current ones.

‘A no-deal exit would enormously increase pressure on our law and security authorities and on our judicial system. The UK would be less safe as a result of this.’

Sir Mark warns no-deal could lead to the break-up of the UK, saying: ‘The stability of the union would be dislocated.’

He says Northern Ireland would face ‘more severe’ consequences, particularly as the lack of devolved government would require direct rule from London.

‘The running of Northern Ireland under No Deal is a sensitive issue,’ he says. ‘The current powers granted to the Northern Irish secretary would not be adequate for the pace, breadth or controversy of the decisions needed to be taken through a no-deal exit. Therefore we would have to introduce direct rule.

Updated at 11.56am BST

9.44am BST

According to the Times’ Sam Coates, cabinet is not going to run for five hours. It will be more like three and a half hours, he says.

9.41am BST

Today’s cabinet started at 9.30am, not 9am as we had previously been told, Sky reports.

Here are some of the ministers arriving.

Updated at 11.56am BST

9.28am BST

Barnier claims some Brexiters want to 'destroy EU'

Barnier says some outside the EU, and some people within it too, see Brexit as a means of weakening the EU.

The EU must respond, he says.

He says this came up at at meeting he held with Nigel Farage, the former Ukip leader. He says he asked Farage how he saw the UK’s future relationship with the EU after Brexit. Farage said, after Brexit, the EU would “no longer exist”. Barnier goes on:

So these people want to destroy the European Union from inside, and others from outside.

Barnier says that is why people have to defend the European Union.

EU countries must stick together,.

Updated at 11.57am BST

9.24am BST

Barnier says future of EU is more important than Brexit

Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator, is speaking in the European parliament now.

He says in the House of Commons there have only been majorities against things.

That is not how an orderly withdrawal can be managed, he says.

If the UK is to avoid a no-deal Brexit, there is only one way forward: to vote for a deal.

And there is only one treaty available, he says. He holds up a copy of the withdrawal agreement.

He says the option of no deal looks “very likely”. It is not the option he would have gone for, he says. You do not need a negotiator for no deal. But the EU has spent a lot of time over the last few months preparing for this.

He says that at the start of this process, Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, said the future of the EU was more important than Brexit. He agrees, he says.

  • Barnier says the future of the EU is more important than Brexit.

Updated at 11.58am BST

9.17am BST

Barnier says extending article 50 again to help UK would pose 'significant risks' to EU

Good morning. As the Brexit crisis deepens, Theresa May is just starting to chair what is scheduled to be a five-hour cabinet, where ministers will discuss what can be done to avert a looming no-deal Brexit on Friday week.

As my colleague Daniel Boffey reports, in Brussels Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief negotiator, has said a no-deal Brexit is becoming “day after day more likely”.

Related: No-deal Brexit 'more likely by the day' says Michel Barnier

Barnier said that, if the Commons did not vote for the withdrawal agreement within the next few days, only two options would remain: “Leaving without an agreement or requesting a longer extension of the article 50 period”.

On Friday May hinted that, if she could not get her deal through parliament, her preference would be to go for a longish article 50 extension, requiring the UK to take part in the European elections.

But this morning Barnier insisted the EU would need a “strong justification” for such a move. EU leaders are due to discuss Brexit at a summit a week tomorrow, and Barnier’s comments implied that they might refuse another delay to Brexit. He said:

The UK may ask for another extension. Such an extension would carry significant risks for the EU. Therefore a strong justification would be needed.

He said businesses in the EU had warned Brussels “against the cost of extending uncertainty”. The UK prolonging its status as a member state while still seeking to leave with a negotiated deal “could pose a risk on our decision-making autonomy”, he added.

Here is the agenda for the day.

9.30am: Theresa May chairs a lengthy cabinet meeting. First there will be a political cabinet, lasting for perhaps two hours, and after that there will be a normal cabinet.

11.30am: Foreign Office questions in the Commons.

After 12.30pm: MPs debate a report admonishing Dominic Cummings, the campaign director of Vote Leave, for contempt of parliament because he refused to give evidence to a Commons inquiry into “fake news” and disinformation.

As usual, I will also be covering breaking political news as it happens, as well as bringing you the best reaction, comment and analysis from the web, but I expect to be focusing mostly on Brexit. I plan to post a summary at lunchtime and another when I wrap up in the afternoon.

You can read all the latest Guardian politics articles here. Here is the Politico Europe round-up of this morning’s political news. And here is the PoliticsHome list of today’s top 10 must-reads.

If you want to follow me or contact me on Twitter, I’m on @AndrewSparrow.

I try to monitor the comments BTL but it is impossible to read them all. If you have a direct question, do include “Andrew” in it somewhere and I’m more likely to find it. I do try to answer questions, and if they are of general interest, I will post the question and reply ATL, although I can’t promise to do this for everyone.

If you want to attract my attention quickly, it is probably better to use Twitter.

fields.bodyText: That’s all from us this evening, so here’s a summary of the day’s events: The prime minister said she planned to ask the European Union for a further delay to Brexit. Speaking from Downing Street, Theresa May said she understood some people’s desire for a no-deal Brexit but that she wanted time to find a settlement. Any delay would end if and when a deal was struck, she said. The president of the European council, Donald Tusk, appeared to indicate the EU was minded to accede. Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn are to meet to discuss a way to break the Brexit impasse. In the same address, the prime minister invited the Labour leader to talks on Tuesday after seven hours of cabinet discussions. Corbyn accepted the offer soon afterwards. It followed MPs’ failure to find an alternative way forward on Monday. May’s plan called for the two leaders to agree a unified approach to put to MPs. If they couldn’t do so, the prime minister said she’d put forward a series of options and abide by MPs’ choice – as long as Corbyn also agreed to do the same. Cabinet ministers were tight-lipped after their marathon meeting, amid reports of a split. Afterwards, the environment secretary Michael Gove spoke publicly in support of the prime minister’s approach. But many senior Brexiters were unimpressed with May’s plan. Some members of the Tory backbench ERG attacked it, as did the DUP. Other senior parliamentarians, however, applauded the prime minister’s decision to try – after nearly three years – to find a consensus across the aisle. Business leaders offered a cautious welcome. But many said they wanted to see Westminster get on with offering certainty over Brexit. Earlier in the day, the Irish prime minister had said May must have a clear plan to be granted a further delay. Speaking alongside the French president, Emmanuel Macron, Leo Varadkar said the EU wanted to avoid a rolling Brexit. The prime minister was accused of putting her party before the country. Nick Boles spoke out a day after quitting the Tory party over what he characterised as its intransigence over Brexit. But he was one of those to cautiously welcome May’s change of approach after her speech in the evening. If you want to read more, my colleagues Rowena Mason, Peter Walker, Rajeev Syal and Heather Stewart have the full story: The hard Brexit-supporting DUP have released a statement on Theresa May’s offer to Jeremy Corbyn and, like the assessments of members of the similarly positioned ERG, it is scathing: The prime minister’s lamentable handling of the negotiations with the EU means she has failed to deliver a sensible Brexit deal that works for all parts of the United Kingdom. That is why she has not been able to get it through parliament. Her announcement therefore tonight comes as little surprise. Though it remains to be seen if subcontracting out the future of Brexit to Jeremy Corbyn, someone whom the Conservatives have demonised for four years, will end happily. We want the result of the referendum respected and, just as we joined the common market as one country, we must leave the EU as one country. We will continue to use our position within Parliament and with the government to argue strongly the case for Northern Ireland and the integrity of the United Kingdom. We remain consistent in judging all Brexit outcomes against our clear unionist principles. Boris Johnson has told the BBC that people want politicians in Westminster “not to focus on themselves, but to focus on the needs of the country”. The European Parliament’s Brexit coordinator, Guy Verhofstadt, damns May with faint praise: A little more from Gove’s interview on Sky News: He insisted the Tory party would not split over May’s decision today. I don’t think we’re splitting – I think what we’re doing is ensuring everybody is focused on making sure we leave the EU at the earliest possible point. On the DUP saying they could not back the current deal, he said: We want the DUP to support our approach. I think it’s important we leave the EU as one UK. And, on his own leadership ambitions, he added: I’m concentrating on making sure we leave the EU, that is front and centre of my mind and everything else is secondary. There is now a conflicting report on the split in the cabinet, with another source telling the Press Association that ministers voted 17 to four in favour of the limited extension sought by the prime minister. Gavin Williamson, Penny Mordaunt, Chris Grayling and Liz Truss opposed the extension, according to the source. Of the 17 who backed it, Jeremy Wright and James Brokenshire made a point of saying they only wanted a short extension to the Article 50 process. The source said: “This is a pragmatic way forward. PM clear that we won’t leave with no deal in April.” The environment secretary, Michael Gove, is now on Sky News defending the proposal, saying its most important facet is that it is limited and ends, unequivocally, with Brexit. His former Vote Leave colleague, Boris Johnson, is less enthused: The director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, Carolyn Fairbairn, has echoed the words of other business leaders this evening, saying: Welcome steps must be breakthrough, not false dawn. Business confidence slumping, growth stalled and UK reputation in tatters. Tories must compromise on red lines and Labour come to table in good faith. No excuses, no time wasting, no party politics. Enough is enough. Dr Adam Marshall, the Director General of the British Chambers of Commerce, said: The clock is still ticking and avoiding a messy and disorderly exit from the EU is still the top priority for our business communities. The government must take firm action now to ensure that this is not allowed to happen by default. Yet businesses need to see outcomes, not just more process. William Hague, the former Conservative leader and former foreign secretary, says in the Daily Telegraph (paywall) that the next party leader could inherit a “ruin”. He says: The Conservative party, I sense, is in danger of losing the support of hopeful young people with ambitions, and it cannot win elections without such people. Moreover, the Conservatives are inevitably identified with the Brexit project, for good or ill, and slowly, steadily, the case for Brexit is being lost. I say that with regret, because by far the best course after the 2016 referendum has been to deliver Brexit and make a go of it. Now, however, a slow movement is taking place out there that makes it rather doubtful that people would vote for it again. Perhaps for the first time, everyone is talking about it, and they are beginning to notice that the trade deals are not so easy, the process of leaving extremely complicated and the keenest Brexiteers deeply divided among themselves. Most people haven’t changed their minds, but I meet some who have, as shown in polls as well. The Conservatives thus face the terrible double prospect of voters shifting away from supporting their central policy, while those who do support it become enraged by the failure to deliver it. That’s why there is nothing guaranteed about having 316 seats in the Commons, nothing at all certain about having a Conservative government, and every possibility of leadership candidates finding they are leading not very much at all. Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair’s former communications chief and a prominent People’s Vote campaigner, has written in the New European a speech he thinks Theresa May should give. He would like her to abandon her deal, and act as a neutral umpire in a referendum. He imagines May saying: The Brexit side must be obliged to submit a plan that is clear, credible, deliverable, negotiable in Europe, rooted in the real world. And those who argue for staying in must also address the concerns people have that led so many to want to leave the EU. I shall be, now and in any referendum which follows, neutral as this straight choice is developed. Real plans have to be brought forward and agreed by both sides as the choice we put to the country. This process needs time. The worst thing we could do is snatch at a solution based on the indicative votes process, which has failed to deliver the clarity many hoped it would. I shall therefore be requesting a long extension from the EU. I have indicated my intentions to several of my fellow leaders and I am confident we will get the time needed. This is from the BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg. This would be no great surprise in the light of the repeated hints being dropped in the chamber by John Bercow, the Speaker, about how he is going to apply a hardline interpretation of the rule about not putting the same proposition to a vote twice. Last week he said he would not allow a repeat vote on the PM’s deal just because support for it had gone up, and that he thought MPs needed protection from being asked to take the same difficult voting decision more than once. Yesterday, after the Tory Brexiter Richard Drax used a point of order to say he bitterly regretted voting for the PM’s deal on Friday and that it must “never ever see the light of day again”, Bercow responded by saying: [Drax] is a person of integrity and a man of principle. I respect what he said, and I think it stands for others to judge, but I appreciate his saying so candidly what he wanted to say. We’ve had the regular No 10 morning briefing, but with a lengthy cabinet meeting (it will “last as long as it lasts”, we were told) still going on, there was not much new to learn. Theresa May’s spokesman was asked for the reaction to last night’s indicative votes, and he told reporters: It is the second time that the house has considered a wide variety of options for a way forward, and it once again failed to find a clear majority in favour of any of those options. The government continues to believe it’s in the best interests of the country to leave with a deal. As you know, cabinet is meeting today to give further consideration to the results and how we should proceed. And that was pretty much it. Nigel Farage, the former Ukip leader, has responded to Michel Barnier’s comment about Farage and some fellow Brexiters wanting to “destroy the EU”. (See 9.28am.) The European commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, has called for EU member states to remain united as the UK grapples with Brexit. “You saw that the British parliament was unable to make a decision yesterday that would move towards a solution agreed by all,” he said after a meeting with the Italian prime minister, Giuseppe Conte, in Rome on Tuesday. “The government is in session this morning ... we await the outcome of this meeting,” he added, while referring back to his comments last week comparing the British parliament to an Egyptian sphinx. “If we compare the sphinx and Great Britain, the sphinx would look like an open book,” he said. Nowadays, he told a public meeting on Peace vs Justice at Inner Temple Hall in central London, they buttonhole him and tell him that politics wasn’t so chaotic in his day. Straw, who was in the Labour cabinet during the Iraq war, defended the legality of the conflict and also disclosed that he regretted having to release General Augusto Pinochet after he was given evidence that the Chilean dictator was not medically fit to stand trial. Here is more on what Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator, told the European parliament’s committee on foreign affairs this morning. I have taken the quotes from the Press Association. Barnier said the crisis in the UK went beyond Brexit. He said: I don’t think I need to go on at great length about the nature of what is going on in the UK, the impasse or political crisis they might be experiencing. More deeply, it is not just about the question of Brexit. I don’t think it’s just about the question of Brexit and the agreement that’s on the table and the backstop for Ireland. It is more broad than that. Somewhere along the line, it is a crisis that equally could have sprung up in another country. In my country [France] as well, there are questions about what our relationship is to the world, what is our place in the EU, what is our economic model. These are all things coming out as a result of the British debate as well. He said a no-deal Brexit would threaten UK-EU cooperation on security. He said: We need to be aware of the implications of a no-deal for our security partnership. There will be a break in the level of talks, less mutual commitment, risks to intelligence pooling. There might be inconsistencies in applying sanctions regimes because of a low level of cooperation. The UK would no longer be taking part in EU operations or in the European Defence Agency’s capacity-building programmes ... No deal for some time poses the threat of there being no organised framework... Come what may, we must fend off the risk of strategic divergence. He said a no-deal Brexit would sour relations between the UK and the EU. He said: If there is no deal, the atmosphere will be different. The lack of a deal means a lack of faith, a lack of a deal means a rupture in confidence between us. He said a no-deal Brexit would not remove issues like Ireland and the UK’s financial contribution to the EU from the debate because as soon as the UK opened trade talks with the EU, these issues would reappear. In response to a question from a British MEP, he said: [After no deal] there won’t be many months passing before the UK will start asking for negotiations on a free trade agreement or other issues, like transport. The topics of Brexit will still be there – Ireland, the financial resolution, the legal obligations of the UK, the issues of citizens and citizens’ rights. These are questions we will put again and again. If there is no deal and the UK wants to discuss trade or other subjects, we will put the same subjects back on the table. He says this came up at at meeting he held with Nigel Farage, the former Ukip leader. He says he asked Farage how he saw the UK’s future relationship with the EU after Brexit. Farage said, after Brexit, the EU would “no longer exist”. Barnier goes on: So these people want to destroy the European Union from inside, and others from outside. Barnier says that is why people have to defend the European Union. EU countries must stick together,. Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator, is speaking in the European parliament now. He says in the House of Commons there have only been majorities against things. That is not how an orderly withdrawal can be managed, he says. If the UK is to avoid a no-deal Brexit, there is only one way forward: to vote for a deal. And there is only one treaty available, he says. He holds up a copy of the withdrawal agreement. He says the option of no deal looks “very likely”. It is not the option he would have gone for, he says. You do not need a negotiator for no deal. But the EU has spent a lot of time over the last few months preparing for this. He says that at the start of this process, Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, said the future of the EU was more important than Brexit. He agrees, he says. Barnier says the future of the EU is more important than Brexit. Good morning. As the Brexit crisis deepens, Theresa May is just starting to chair what is scheduled to be a five-hour cabinet, where ministers will discuss what can be done to avert a looming no-deal Brexit on Friday week.
